title: Basic Statistics Calculator
description: Calculates common epidemiological values for diagnostic tests and treatments, including sensitivity, specificity, predictive values, likelihood ratios, and treatment effectiveness measures.

parameters.name: calculation_type
parameters.description: Type of calculation to perform: 'diagnostic_test' or 'treatment'

parameters.name: input_method
parameters.description: Method of input for diagnostic test: 'rates' (prevalence, sensitivity, specificity) or 'counts' (TP, FP, FN, TN)

parameters.name: experimental_with_outcome
parameters.description: Number of experimental patients with outcome (A)

parameters.name: experimental_without_outcome
parameters.description: Number of experimental patients without outcome (B)

parameters.name: control_with_outcome
parameters.description: Number of control patients with outcome (C)

parameters.name: control_without_outcome
parameters.description: Number of control patients without outcome (D)

interpretation.description: Statistical measures for evidence-based medicine decision making
guidelines: Sensitivity: probability of positive test when disease is present
Specificity: probability of negative test when disease is absent
PPV: probability of disease when test is positive
NPV: probability of no disease when test is negative
LR+: how much more likely a positive test is in someone with the disease
LR-: how much more likely a negative test is in someone without the disease
NNT: number of patients needed to treat to prevent one adverse outcome

references: Altman DG, Bland JM. Diagnostic tests. 1: Sensitivity and specificity. BMJ. 1994 Jun 11;308(6943):1552.
Van der Helm HJ, Hische EA. Application of Bayes's theorem to results of quantitative clinical chemical determinations. Clin Chem. 1979 Jun;25(6):985-8.
Akobeng AK. Understanding diagnostic tests 1: sensitivity, specificity and predictive values. Acta Paediatr. 2007 Mar;96(3):338-41.
Laupacis A, Sackett DL, Roberts RS. An assessment of clinically useful measures of the consequences of treatment. N Engl J Med. 1988 Jun 30;318(26):1728-33.
formula: Multiple formulas based on calculation type
notes: To practice evidence-based medicine, apply statistics and results of scientific studies to individual patients using clinical judgment
Confidence intervals are calculated using standard methods where applicable
For diagnostic tests, either rates or counts can be provided as input
